newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan Semicon issues US$300 mln bonds.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan Semicon issues US$300 mln bonds.

text.p: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, Taiwan's largest semiconductor maker, said on Saturday it had issued US$300 million in European convertible bonds to finance the company's future expansion.
"We issue the bonds mainly to raise funds needed to install the facilities of our fourth and fifth wafer fabrication plants," the company said in a statement.

Taiwan Semiconductor has embarked on an ambitious expansion. In mid-April, it announced it would build six advanced wafer-fabrication plants as part of a T$400 billion investment at southern Taiwan's Tainan Science-based Industrial Park.
The bonds were scheduled to be listed at the stock exchange in Luxembourg from July 3, and the company granted the underwriter an over-allotment option of up to US$50 million, it said.
The five-year bonds were over-subscribed 700 percent during a five-day road show, U.S.-based underwriter Goldman Sachs said.
The bonds, one of the largest issues ever made by a local company, can be redeemed at maturity together with the principal plus interest of 36.23 percent.
The conversion price is T$144, which is a premium of 20 percent of the common share closing price as of June 26, 1997, the statement said.
Taiwan Semiconductor is the world's largest custom maker of integrated circuits.
The firm's foundry business does not design and sell its own IC products, but custom makes them according to customers' applications.
